name: The Family & Youth Institute
mission: Redefining the narrative on Muslim mental health and well-being and championing a world where individuals, families, and communities are empowered and flourishing.
theoryOfChange: The Family & Youth Institute explicitly states, 'the fyi's theory of change. How We Do It.' on their research page. They describe their approach as a 'community-based participatory research approach' that ensures projects are 'grounded in community spirit and collaboration' and 'bridging community, research, and practice.' Their mission is to strengthen and empower individuals, families, and communities through research and education, focusing on Muslim Americans' well-being through 'community-centered research, solution-seeking, and education' to promote mental health and well-being.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://thefyi.org/zakat (Source: https://thefyi.org/zakat)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Limited match due to weaker results and/or higher uncertainty; review methodology details before deciding.

components.evidence: Explicit zakat program (+4); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Humanitarian service (+2)
components.improvement_suggestion: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

alignment.rationale: Alignment 29/50: MEDIUM Muslim donor fit, advocacy cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data; good program ratio (≥75%) suggests reasonable delivery
components.improvement_suggestion: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: If reserves are above policy target, document why and publish triggers for planned deployment.
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes over at least 3 years.
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

components.evidence: Board governance: baseline (2 members, emerging org)
components.name: Governance

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Board too small: 2 members

score_details.score_summary: THE FAMILY AND YOUTH INSTITUTE shows good impact and good alignment, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied). Evidence score may reflect limited reporting capacity, not program weakness.

zakat.claim_evidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://thefyi.org/zakat (Source: https://thefyi.org/zakat)

all_citations.claim: The FYI focuses on mental health research, community education, and aging projects while maintaining specific financial health metrics.
The organization reported total revenue of $850,837 and a program expense ratio of 83.6%.
The organization provides multiple giving methods for donors to support its research and education efforts.
The Family and Youth Institute is zakat-eligible and maintains a specific zakat policy for its programs.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization demonstrates strong internal financial management and efficiency, though its overall score is moderated by low data confidence and a capacity-building impact model.
areas_for_improvement: Limited external data confidence and third-party impact verification.
Narrower donor alignment profile compared to larger national advocacy groups.

dimension_explanations.alignment: The organization is Zakat-eligible and serves specific community needs through research and advocacy [4]. The alignment score is medium, reflecting a balanced fit for donors interested in mental health and youth development, though it lacks the high urgency often associated with immediate humanitarian relief [1][3].
dimension_explanations.impact: The FYI focuses on capacity building through community education and mental health research, allocating 83.6% of its expenses toward these programs [1][2]. While financial health is strong with 23.6 months of working capital, the overall impact score reflects a lack of third-party evidence regarding specific long-term outcomes [1].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Family and Youth Institute strengthens community well-being through research-backed mental health education and positive youth development programs.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 83.6%, indicating a strong focus on direct service delivery.
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with a cost of only $0.09 per $1 raised.
Robust financial stability with 23.6 months of working capital available.
baseline_narrative.summary: The Family and Youth Institute (The FYI) is a research and education organization dedicated to empowering individuals and families through initiatives like the Aging with Dignity Project and mental health research [1]. The organization reported a total revenue of $850,837 and maintains a policy that allows for the collection of zakat-eligible donations to support its community efforts [2][4].
